While the lights are bright and vibrant, the patterns varied, the defect I have encountered makes this a product I would not recommend.

The vibration is almost a deal-breaker, however. Also, the d-pad is awful. history.review_full:
Overall, the grip is a nice upgrade from my usual setup (stock Joy-Con with a Satisfye grip). I tried the Hori Split Pad Pro but it wasn't for me. Seeing as this connects directly into the Switch, I thought it would be great to use for games that demand little to no latency, such as Smash and Metroid. Both games performed well. The sticks here have full axes; they even come with extra nubs that you can swap. I have mine laid out similar to the GameCube sticks: larger left nub, narrow right nub. The back buttons are easy to program and press, though the white-light indicator was pale enough for me to not recognize it at first.

The vibration is almost a deal-breaker, however. It's too strong and the instructions that came with don't acknowledge a way to change the intensity. They make the whole grip quake, resulting in an annoying plastic chatter. It deafens a lot of the audio coming from the game. Also, the d-pad is awful. I don't have unintended inputs, but it's almost impossible to do so because the d-pad requires a bit more force than Nintendo's own d-pad. That and the shape of the d-pad itself make it uncomfortable to use for any game that requires long use of it.

history.review_excerpt:
It's great how companies manufacture different ways of making the gaming experience enjoyable.

So I'm always down to try a new controller. No controller is ever perfect; I might have a few go-tos for different genres, but having a favorite means I won't have a favorite later. It's also in the shape of the Xbox controller, which is super comfortable.

In the hand, this controllers feels great. I know they use Hall-effect switches (which also were used in keyboards long ago), and I'm aware of the technology behind it; I have no doubt they will prove better in the long run too, but I'm also curious as to what issues may be presented that haven't yet.

There are a couple issues I have with the controller that I'll mention now.
history.review_full:
I'm a controller junkie. I have controllers from old systems that I've rigged to work on modern systems, and even controllers for systems I don't have. It's great how companies manufacture different ways of making the gaming experience enjoyable.

So I'm always down to try a new controller. No controller is ever perfect; I might have a few go-tos for different genres, but having a favorite means I won't have a favorite later. I've read around about this GuliKit controller. The technology checks out: Hall-effect sticks, mechanical buttons, and metal parts? Count me in! It's also in the shape of the Xbox controller, which is super comfortable.

In the hand, this controllers feels great. It's got a soft, matte-like texture. It's not rubbery to the touch, but more of a grainy plastic. The area around the sticks are metal, but I'm unsure of the triggers. They feel plastic without me removing them. The buttons feel awesome. They're my favorite next to Nintendo's ABXY buttons. Because the buttons use a mechanical switch, there will be less wear-and-tear in the long run. They can be switched around for an Xbox-style layout, but I'm leaving mine as they came.

The sticks are nice and snappy. They always snap into the center and feel good to move. I know they use Hall-effect switches (which also were used in keyboards long ago), and I'm aware of the technology behind it; I have no doubt they will prove better in the long run too, but I'm also curious as to what issues may be presented that haven't yet.

There are a couple issues I have with the controller that I'll mention now. One is the positioning of the OS buttons. There's start and minus akin to the Switch, as well as menu, screen-capture, and a controller-setting buttons. I wish the menu and screen-capture buttons were swapped with the start and select buttons. I found myself several times pressing menu or screen capture when I meant to press start and select. The former buttons are placed where start and select normally are (at least for me), so I've had lots of accidental presses. I hope there's an update in the future that lets me customize any button.

Another issue is the triggers. The back triggers have too much real estate, leaving the front triggers uncomfortable to press. I know this is completely dependent on the user's hands, but my index fingers rest on the triggers and I have to twist my hand to press the front triggers. This is a problem in games like Metroid Dread, which make heavy use of the front triggers. I know the Switch can swap buttons, but it doesn't eliminate the discomfort.

Those are my only issues. Overall, I love this controller. The controller settings are another feature I love. Using just the settings button and other button combos, I can change the vibration intensity (thank you!), the distance of the sticks, and the distance of the back triggers, which I believe are digital with some analog distance. Gyro settings can be adjusted too but I never use that.

product.title: GuliKit Kingkong 2 Pro Hall Effect Wireless Bluetooth Controller for NS Switch, Windows PC,MacOS,Android And iOS,Gamepad with Joysticks,Auto Pilot Gaming Button(Black)

heldout.review_excerpt:
Let's list the upgrades:
- grip
- analog sticks
- two more shoulder buttons
- vibration
- Switch/PC buttons
- wireless (and 2.4 GHz to boot!), with both a dongle for the GameCube and one for USB

Already this is the perfect upgrade to the Hori Digital Controller. I'm unsure whether there's an option to change the strength, but the manual doesn't indicate that so I don't think so. The controller is already light enough, but the quality of the plastic is very light and feels hollow. I have relatively small hands (5'8", so whatever size hand that coordinates to) and haven't moved the stick accidentally, but I always feel it when pressing the B button.
heldout.review_full:
The Hori Digital Controller for the GameCube is one of my “grail” controllers. For over a decade I've casually eyed this controller, seeing its price rise from high double digits to what it is now. Still, I don't think the price is that bad for such a unique controller. I love it when companies take their own, fresh perspective on standard controller layouts without making them unwieldy. Comfort is usually the driving force for change, as well as quality-of-life improvements. 8BitDo has been doing a fantastic job in this regard, and now Retro Fighters isn't far behind.

Retro Fighters (“RF”) is doing wonderful things in the controller world. My first controller was the Brawler64 when it came out in different colors. (While I was aware of the Kickstarter, I avoided it out of personal reasons with Kickstarter itself.) It was love at first touch. It perfectly conformed to my hand and felt wonderful. The d-pad could use some refinement, but overall it's great. Fast-forwarding through a bunch of controllers, we arrive at the BladeGC. I knew I had to have it. Initially, I thought 8BitDo would release a controller like this, or at least some other company, so I was super excited when Retro Fighters announced it. Though I'd still like to get the Hori one some day, it's no longer a must; it's wired and doesn't have features for modern systems. Let's list the upgrades:
- grip
- analog sticks
- two more shoulder buttons
- vibration
- Switch/PC buttons
- wireless (and 2.4 GHz to boot!), with both a dongle for the GameCube and one for USB

Already this is the perfect upgrade to the Hori Digital Controller. The little Z button is missing on the front, but of course it's not a requirement.

I'll start with commenting on the d-pad. It's…phenomenal. I'm *very* picky about d-pads. Nintendo's of course are best, with Hori a close second. 8BitDo's may feel nice, but they have a habit of mis-presses. This can be remedied by opening the controller and applying binder reinforcement tabs; not ideal, but definitely alleviates the issue. But this d-pad? Damn… My thumb *skates* across it. When I first opened it, I was a bit disappointed with how it felt. It's low and has straight corners. But during play is when I noticed how marvelous it is. I tried Crash Team Racing, Stardew Valley, and Shredder's Revenge. Every input was precise and correct, and my thumb was able to just skate across it with speed and accuracy. Mein Gott.

I haven't extensively used the analog sticks since I didn't get this controller for them, but I tested them with Smash. There's an octagonal gate for each stick, and each movement was comfortable and, for the time I spent using them, precise as well. They're smooth but don't let your thumbs slide off. The tops are flat, with the outer ring (textured for gripping pleasure) jutting up just enough to prevent thumbs from steering off. They don't have as wide an area to move as the GameCube controller, or maybe that's because they're not as tall, but they work well enough. Because of how wonderful this controller feels, I now plan to get the BattlerGC.

The vibration is subtle. I'm unsure whether there's an option to change the strength, but the manual doesn't indicate that so I don't think so. It's not too low so as not to feel it; in fact, I think it's the perfect strength if you prefer a little feedback without it dominating the hands. I've had some third-party controllers that freakin' rattled the whole controller. Super uncomfortable. The BladeGC's gives you just a small jolt to remind you that you got hit, loser.

And the wireless connectivity? A non-issue. Since this is not Bluetooth, it can't be used with the Switch when in handheld mode; instead, the USB dongle plugs directly to the dock. The Switch then reads it as a wired controller (which must be turned on in settings) and away you go. There is no discernible lag from what I noticed.

Now on to the “bad.”

Material. The controller is already light enough, but the quality of the plastic is very light and feels hollow. There is no grip texture. Rather, the whole thing is smooth and my hands can slide a bit easily. This is something I noticed with other RF controllers, so I know it isn't just this. Based on how it feels, it doesn't feel like a premium controller, though I certainly consider it one.

Stick placement. There is little distance between the right stick and the B button. I have relatively small hands (5'8", so whatever size hand that coordinates to) and haven't moved the stick accidentally, but I always feel it when pressing the B button. This made me wonder how people with bigger thumbs will experience the controller.

But that's it. No more bad. Everything good. Oh, maybe the back shoulder buttons. I prefer ones that stop with a noticeable press, but these go just straight down like a lot of modern shoulder buttons. Gross. Maybe the sticks can be bigger too, but I'll wait until I try the BattlerGC to comment on that.

This will be my main controller for RPGs, or any other game that utilizes the d-pad and A button a lot.

B for materials and stick placement, A+ for everything else.
heldout.review_title: Nearly flawless, but flawless for RPGs.

history.review_excerpt:
If you already have that version on your Win10 PC, you will need to download Razer Synapse 2.0 (currently 2.21.21.1) to be able to make adjustments via software to the backlighting and the key assignments.

Unfortunately, the 2.0 software can’t load the image of the keyboard when you go to the configurations, so it’s hard to program the keys with the software. Also, having two versions of Razer Synapse on my PC played havoc with my Internet connection when I was connected to Razer Central--different browsers refused to connect to web sites (even Google) on the basis that my connection wasn’t secure, even though the connection had been secure by default. I like the “tactile, clicky” feature very much, but question whether the keyboard is worth the Amazon price (about $66) when the 2.0 software has the problems that it has.
history.review_full:
First, this RAZER BLACK WIDOW ULTIMATE ESPORTS GAMING KEYBOARD (Green Mechanical Switches (Tactile and Clicky)) is NOT a “Chroma” keyboard that allows you to change the backlighting color with Razer Synapse software. Instead the backlighting color is green only, and is subject to software adjustment in overall brightness and contrast only.

Second, this keyboard does NOT work with Razer Synapse 3.0, the latest version. If you already have that version on your Win10 PC, you will need to download Razer Synapse 2.0 (currently 2.21.21.1) to be able to make adjustments via software to the backlighting and the key assignments.

Unfortunately, the 2.0 software can’t load the image of the keyboard when you go to the configurations, so it’s hard to program the keys with the software. Also, having two versions of Razer Synapse on my PC played havoc with my Internet connection when I was connected to Razer Central--different browsers refused to connect to web sites (even Google) on the basis that my connection wasn’t secure, even though the connection had been secure by default. It had somehow gotten changed so it was NOT secure.

Fortunately, it is possible to dim the backlighting with the keyboard alone (FN + F11 or F12). It is also possible to program some keys with the keyboard alone (see the poorly written quickstart manual packed in the box lid).

Third, the backlighting is set to maximum brightness by default, and is annoyingly bright until you figure out how to adjust it. Something that I did NOT like is that only the numbers and letters on the keys are backlit. You have to peer at the keys to find the symbols, such as the @ symbol.

Fourth and last, the mechanical keys have a nice feel, and make a soft popping sound as you type. I like the “tactile, clicky” feature very much, but question whether the keyboard is worth the Amazon price (about $66) when the 2.0 software has the problems that it has. I’d rather put my money down on a keyboard that works with Synapse 3.0.
history.review_title: Doesn’t Work With Synapse 3.0 Programming Software; Has Problems With Synapse 2.0 Software

product.title: Razer BlackWidow Ultimate: Esports Gaming Keyboard - Dust and Spill Resistant - Individually Backlit Keys - Razer Green Mechanical Switches (Tactile and Clicky)

history.review_excerpt:
At first, I thought I would really love this large RAZER MAMBA WIRELESS GAMING MOUSE (16,000 DPI Optical Sensor; Chroma RGB Lighting; 7 Programmable Buttons; Mechanical Switches; Up to 50 Hr Battery Life), because it felt so comfortable in my hand. However, it isn’t so easy to use.

Yes, the mouse DPI sensing can be increased so that the cursor really flies across the monitor display, but the mouse movement doesn’t feel effortless to me. It’s a bit clunky as a wired mouse, because the braided cord is thick and heavy.

The Chroma capability is nice--you can set the lighted portions (the Razer symbol on the top and the scrolling wheel) to any color you want, or to set them to cycle through different colors.

You need the free Razer Synapse software to set the Chroma colors, and also to program the buttons.
history.review_full:
At first, I thought I would really love this large RAZER MAMBA WIRELESS GAMING MOUSE (16,000 DPI Optical Sensor; Chroma RGB Lighting; 7 Programmable Buttons; Mechanical Switches; Up to 50 Hr Battery Life), because it felt so comfortable in my hand. However, it isn’t so easy to use.

Yes, the mouse DPI sensing can be increased so that the cursor really flies across the monitor display, but the mouse movement doesn’t feel effortless to me. I have to focus to control the cursor and land on the exact spot I want. In regular use (not gaming), I end up setting the Mouse to a speed below that of my old wired ASUS mouse, so I’m getting no real benefit from the variable DPI settings.

Also, the scrolling wheel always feels loose. For some reason, I don’t get steady or consistent scrolling from the wheel. Maybe I just don’t know how to scroll like an expert.

The mouse works beautifully as a wireless mouse. It’s a bit clunky as a wired mouse, because the braided cord is thick and heavy.

The Chroma capability is nice--you can set the lighted portions (the Razer symbol on the top and the scrolling wheel) to any color you want, or to set them to cycle through different colors.

You need the free Razer Synapse software to set the Chroma colors, and also to program the buttons. The mouse works with Razer Synapse 3.0.
history.review_title: Extremely Comfortable Large Mouse With Chroma Colors

history.review_excerpt:
The major drawback is that all of the illustrations of the art under discussion (paintings, architecture, sculpture, etc.) are printed in black and white.

Actually, because the book’s paper is very cheap, the illustrations are gray and white, and are totally lacking in detail. This problem is alleviated somewhat by the availability of full-color “flash cards” of the art on the Barron’s site, but the illustrations are nevertheless disappointing.

I ordered this book because I have a college degree in art history, and I was curious about the design of AP courses in art history. It makes me kind of sad that the Barron’s book places so much emphasis on dry facts (e.g., dates, current locations of the art, artists’ materials, artists’ biographies, etc.).
history.review_full:
This BARRON’S AP ART HISTORY WITH ONLINE TESTS book holds an enormous amount of art history review material, many practice AP tests, and clear explanations of why the correct answers are correct. The major drawback is that all of the illustrations of the art under discussion (paintings, architecture, sculpture, etc.) are printed in black and white.

Actually, because the book’s paper is very cheap, the illustrations are gray and white, and are totally lacking in detail. This problem is alleviated somewhat by the availability of full-color “flash cards” of the art on the Barron’s site, but the illustrations are nevertheless disappointing.

I ordered this book because I have a college degree in art history, and I was curious about the design of AP courses in art history. It makes me kind of sad that the Barron’s book places so much emphasis on dry facts (e.g., dates, current locations of the art, artists’ materials, artists’ biographies, etc.). Apparently this is what is tested in the AP exam, but having to memorize all those facts and canned answers about periods in art history takes the joy out of studying fine art.

This book should provide everything that a student needs to obtain a high score on the AP art history exam.
history.review_title: Enormous Amount of Review Material, Many Practice Tests, Clearly Explained Answers

product.title: Barron's AP Art History, 4th Edition: With Bonus Online Tests

history.review_excerpt:
These RAZER DOUBLESHOT PBT KEYCAPS (for Mechanical & Optical Keyboards: Compatible with Standard 104/105 US and UK layouts; Razer Green) work great with my Razer BlackWidow Ultimate keyboard. I have always loved the keyboard, because it’s so customizable, but have hated the lack of keycap backlighting for the uppercase symbols. I’m a touch typist, but have a bad habit of peeking at the number keys to get the uppercase symbols.

As you can see from my photo, these keycaps solve the problem. You do have to remember that the label on the left is for the lower case (usually a number) key, but that’s easy to do.

It’s too bad that the keycaps for the BlackWidow Ultimate keyboard weren’t designed like this in the first place.
history.review_full:
These RAZER DOUBLESHOT PBT KEYCAPS (for Mechanical & Optical Keyboards: Compatible with Standard 104/105 US and UK layouts; Razer Green) work great with my Razer BlackWidow Ultimate keyboard. I have always loved the keyboard, because it’s so customizable, but have hated the lack of keycap backlighting for the uppercase symbols. I’m a touch typist, but have a bad habit of peeking at the number keys to get the uppercase symbols.

As you can see from my photo, these keycaps solve the problem. By placing the number and symbol labels side by side at the top, both are properly backlit. You do have to remember that the label on the left is for the lower case (usually a number) key, but that’s easy to do.

It’s too bad that the keycaps for the BlackWidow Ultimate keyboard weren’t designed like this in the first place. The box of keycaps comes with a keycap puller, as well as with stabilizers for the larger keys. The instructions are very easy to understand, and swapping out the keycaps is a simple job.
history.review_title: Solves BlackWidow Keyboard Problem of No Backlighting for Upper Case Symbols

product.title: Razer Doubleshot PBT Keycap Upgrade Set for Mechanical & Optical Keyboards: Compatible with Standard 104/105 US and UK layouts - Classic Black

history.review_full:
EDIT/UPDATE: This strap is still doing really well. Shortly after this review (Sep 2021), once I discovered Supernatural-Workout near, go far fitness app, I have been using it every single day for 60+ minutes at a time. I basically commandeered my husbands Oculus, and have been the only one using it. ZERO ISSUES. Now it is the end of December and I figured I would mention how well it has been holding up.

This strap takes some pressure off my cheekbones. I could feel the difference right away. The head strap is a significant upgrade over the default strap. My husband and I are currently sharing the Oculus, and we're always having to adjust the strap. I think my head it bigger. Adjusting this strap is as easy as a turn of a dial. SO MUCH BETTER, easier, more comfortable. We both are really liking this so far.

The silicon face cover is much better than the one that ships with the Oculus Quest 2. It is more robust, and I can feel the difference both when holding one in each hand, and once on the VR-- it is just more comfortable. ALSO, it has more material in the nose bridge area, which helps to fill up any gaps. There is a slit in the longer material which allows it to comfortably fit around various noses. Before I could see the floor and outside light, now it is pretty much all gone.

This strap simply feels more secure over the default. Everything about it more comfortable and natural feeling.

As for the battery pack holder, we currently do not have a battery pack to use so I cant comment on how well it holds one. But I can say that it is similar to a phone holder-- uses tension to hold it in place. I dont notice any added weight, or at least nothing that makes it uncomfortable by the addition of a more robust head strap and battery pack holder.

The cut out of material that leads toward rear of the strap is not perfect. I dont see it impacting anything unless it peels off. Hopefully all remains good there.

I am really quite pleased SO FAR. You better believe I will be back to update immediately if I experience anything bad, but I will also update if I experience/notice anything else worth sharing.

I hemmed and hawed between a 4 and 5. 4 only because I havent had this long, but 5 because if it continues to be a good working item then it is something I would easily recommend for someone to try. The current price of <$40 (and now there is a coupon for a few bucks off), makes it competitively priced, and worth trying. Anyway, 5 it is!
history.review_title: takes pressure off cheeks, easily adjusts in size, nose area reduces light gap, really good so far!

It doubles play time without need for a physical battery pack. Nice option for those that use some apps laying down- there is no battery bracket to get in the way.

The Oculus has about 2 hours of run time, or less. I use mine primarily for the workout/fitness app, "Supernatural-workout near, go far". At full charge, I will go 1.5 hours, with maybe 20 minutes left. Totally fine, so long as my Oculus is fully charged. If I want to do anything else, then I need to charge it. Or if anyone else wants to play. I have been meaning to buy a battery pack for my [[ASIN:B094Z85PXS X-super Home Adjustable Elite Strap with Battery Bracket]] but haven't done so yet, I have been just using it every single day as a regular strap. My husband bought me a battery pack but it is way too huge. So when this rechargeable strap came up as an option to try, I figured it was something worth checking out.

The head strap is light and comfortable. The rear hugs the head, SO this is an excellent contender for those that play games, use apps that are conducive to relaxing, laying down. The fit relies entirely on the velcro straps (top & sides). I prefer the additional crank turn knob of my other strap, but this style is pretty popular and must have merit. The battery charges pretty quick. It holds about 2 hours of charge. I dont plan to have it as my daily strap, at least right now. I think I will keep it charged up, and have it on stand by for times I either failed to fully charge my Oculus, or when someone wants to use it after me and needs the extra juice. Or for after my evening workout session, and I want to go lay on the couch comfortably.

Anyway, so far so good. If I experience anything else worth sharing, I will be back to do so.

history.review_excerpt:
The main characters are likeable enough and as things progressed I found myself interested in what was going on and anxious to find out what would happen next.

So then, the Pros: The Graphics, great! While most modern games seem to be going for the "real as life" look this game looks softer, less in your face. None of these things warrant losing even one star so my rating stands at 5 out of 5.

All in all I think this is one of the most refined and polished games I've ever played. This game works and works well.

When the next episode or book in the story is released for the PC I will most certainly buy it too.

5 out of 5 stars for this one and kudos for the developers.
history.review_full:
"Wow," is the best I can think of to say about this game. It's really something and I like it a lot. Usually I only play serious strategy games such as Civilization and my past forays into console games have been far less than satisfactory. Thanks to the other reviewers here I decided to give this one a try and I'm very glad I did.

At first I was wondering if it is just an interactive story. I'm not much for the story aspects of games and it took several scenes before actual game play comes up. Surprisingly, I held in there and after the first couple short missions I was hooked. The story itself is not overly original but also not so common as to be boring. The main characters are likeable enough and as things progressed I found myself interested in what was going on and anxious to find out what would happen next.

So then, the Pros: The Graphics, great! I wasn't sure what to think of the watercolor/cartoon/anime mix at first but after seeing it in action I'm hooked. While most modern games seem to be going for the "real as life" look this game looks softer, less in your face. Also on the plus side of things is the ease of play. It was easy to learn how things work and to understand the goals and objectives set out. I got an Xbox controller to use with it, my first time ever using one, and I'm having a great time with it.

Another plus, to me, is the music. I often turn the music or all sound off when playing games because I usually find it distracting or somehow undesirable. This one is different and interesting is that parts of the music, while certainly different, is reminiscent of songs I've heard, some old and some not so old.

On the Cons side of things I'm coming up a little short. I would prefer to not have go through a configuration launcher every time and sometimes the story plays on emotions in ways I'd rather it didn't. Sometimes the story scenes are a bit long and I would get impatient for the next mission. And of course there's always those times such as when my best gunner totally misses the house sized tank 20 feet in from of him and gets me ranting and wanting an undo/redo/wtf button. But that's part of luck and chance and it wouldn't be a real game without. None of these things warrant losing even one star so my rating stands at 5 out of 5.

All in all I think this is one of the most refined and polished games I've ever played. It's done. Totally complete and playable on initial download. No waiting weeks or months for patches and updates. No hours spent grinding through forums hoping to find a fix for some inane problem. This game works and works well.

When the next episode or book in the story is released for the PC I will most certainly buy it too.

5 out of 5 stars for this one and kudos for the developers. Well Done!

product.title: Valkyria Chronicles - Playstation 3

history.review_excerpt:
This keyboard is nice enough for the price. I haven't tried the razor software so can't speak to it, but this software is much harder to program with than logitech's and even a bit worse than cooler master's.

Example: The worst part of the software is once you have programmed in and edited your macro, you cannot save it. If you decide you want it on a different key, you have to program it into that key. With the logitech software, once you have created a macro you can drag and drop it whereever you want.

So as not to be all about talking up logitech I will say physically I like this keyboard better than any logitech I've used.
history.review_full:
This keyboard is nice enough for the price. It has a good touch for typing and the red lighting shows up surprisingly well. What isn't nice is the programming software. In fact, it's some of the worst I've ever seen. They put almost no effort into it and the result is difficult, tedious and barely useable. If you're very interested in programming macros, get a logitech. I haven't tried the razor software so can't speak to it, but this software is much harder to program with than logitech's and even a bit worse than cooler master's.

Example: The worst part of the software is once you have programmed in and edited your macro, you cannot save it. It is forever bound to the key you selected. If you decide you want it on a different key, you have to program it into that key. With the logitech software, once you have created a macro you can drag and drop it whereever you want.

So as not to be all about talking up logitech I will say physically I like this keyboard better than any logitech I've used. And I've used quite a few.

So, it is easy enough to set up and is easy enough to figure out, but at the same time, it doesn't work as easily as expected. he light is red, then green, then red again, even when you were certain you had it in the right spot.

If you put the slightest amount of pressure on it, then it changes colour. If you leave the battery packs in the controllers as they claim you can when you go to use the charger, it takes hours longer for them to charge, or in any event, for it to recognise that they are charged. Eventually it will charge them, and the battery packs fit nicely in the controllers, but it is rather a pain to use when you never really now if it is charged or not.

At this point, I'm not sure what to think.

history.review_excerpt:
Most of the game is pretty good, but there's a lot that's different in the free roam mode. I like the photo abilities and the choice of vehicles, but honestly, I could have done without the planes and the boats. I like driving games and that was one of the thrills of the first game, especially with the wild run expansion pack.

This game is a bit different and some of the races are too short, some of them are just silly IMO. The graphics are good for the most part and there is a lot to do, but sometimes the other players can be a real pain in the rear end and you can't always get away from them like you can in other games.

Overall, it's okay, but not what I was hoping for based on how great the first one was.
history.review_full:
I like this game well enough, but not as much as the first one. Most of the game is pretty good, but there's a lot that's different in the free roam mode. I like the photo abilities and the choice of vehicles, but honestly, I could have done without the planes and the boats. I like driving games and that was one of the thrills of the first game, especially with the wild run expansion pack.

This game is a bit different and some of the races are too short, some of them are just silly IMO. The graphics are good for the most part and there is a lot to do, but sometimes the other players can be a real pain in the rear end and you can't always get away from them like you can in other games.

Overall, it's okay, but not what I was hoping for based on how great the first one was.
history.review_title: still not as good as the original

product.title: The Crew 2 - PlayStation 4

history.review_excerpt:
I love all of the different farming games, but what i love about this one the most is the amount of animals you can eventually have if you keep working at it. There is freedom to do what you want in this game, including being a goblin fighting miner.

There isn't anything gross or any graphic violence in this game, so it is good for kids and parents alike. There are some difficult to solve puzzles and sometimes finding the lost items in the game can be maddening, but really, overall, there is so much to do if you get stuck doing one thing, then you can easily move on to another.

This truly is a great game, although the graphics are a bit wonky, even though one expects that with these crafting games, it can make it hard on the eyes after a while.
history.review_full:
I love all of the different farming games, but what i love about this one the most is the amount of animals you can eventually have if you keep working at it. Want 500 pigs? No problem. Want to focus on gardening instead? No worries. There is freedom to do what you want in this game, including being a goblin fighting miner.

There isn't anything gross or any graphic violence in this game, so it is good for kids and parents alike. There are some difficult to solve puzzles and sometimes finding the lost items in the game can be maddening, but really, overall, there is so much to do if you get stuck doing one thing, then you can easily move on to another.

This truly is a great game, although the graphics are a bit wonky, even though one expects that with these crafting games, it can make it hard on the eyes after a while.

product.title: Stardew Valley: Collector's Edition - Xbox One

history.review_excerpt:
So this game is really fun in either single player or multiplayer and I like that you can couch co-op with a friend without having to go online. The characters in this are fun to use and their special abilities grow as you continue on with the game. Some portions of it can be challenging and it is truly one of those games where you have to work together if you are going to play in co-op mode.

I like that you never really know what to expect because each new place you come into is different and you have to get a feel for how to get through it before you really make progress. I enjoyed solving the puzzles and fighting the various enemies.
history.review_full:
So this game is really fun in either single player or multiplayer and I like that you can couch co-op with a friend without having to go online. There aren't enough of those games anymore, IMO. The characters in this are fun to use and their special abilities grow as you continue on with the game. Some portions of it can be challenging and it is truly one of those games where you have to work together if you are going to play in co-op mode.

I like that you never really know what to expect because each new place you come into is different and you have to get a feel for how to get through it before you really make progress. There are a lot of hurdles you have to get past and they make it more fun. I enjoyed solving the puzzles and fighting the various enemies.

product.title: Knack (PlayStation 4)

heldout.review_excerpt:
Now that I have been using it for a while, I find the keystroke sound quite pleasant.

The battery life seems pretty good, even with the backlight being on the majority of the time. It does have a sleep mode and it is easy to tell when the battery needs charging by looking at the space bar. I do, however, wish the manual that came with it was a bit more explanatory on the different functions, as I wasn't sure what all the terms meant and what difference the modes make in your typing experience. Otherwise, this is a great product for a price that does not seem unreasonable. I would recommend it to other people who type a lot and are looking for a reliable and comfortable experience.
heldout.review_full:
I really love this keyboard. I was actually surprised when I got the box how heavy and sturdy this product is. I do a lot of typing, and this is perfect for my needs. The keys are deep and have a nice, resounding click that lets you know whether or not you hit the key. The sound isn't intolerable, especially if there are other things going on in your environment. Now that I have been using it for a while, I find the keystroke sound quite pleasant.

The battery life seems pretty good, even with the backlight being on the majority of the time. It does have a sleep mode and it is easy to tell when the battery needs charging by looking at the space bar. This is a very well-built item. It is designed to withstand the rigors of someone who types a lot without breaking down. I like the feel of the keys under my fingers and find that after using it more and more, that I wouldn't want to go back to a different model.

Overall, I'm really impressed with this product. I do, however, wish the manual that came with it was a bit more explanatory on the different functions, as I wasn't sure what all the terms meant and what difference the modes make in your typing experience. Otherwise, this is a great product for a price that does not seem unreasonable. I would recommend it to other people who type a lot and are looking for a reliable and comfortable experience.

history.review_excerpt:
The shape of the headphones themselves looks a little odd and as such I was a little concerned that the fit would be off, but this ended up being a non-issue.

We plugged them into the computer and immediately they lit up. These are not quite audiophile quality but they are better than a lot of more expensive headphones I have used. The detail is there too so there should be no problem hearing more subtle sounds without cranking the volume too high.

The microphone itself is a little tricky to attach but if one pays attention when trying to attach it, it is not all that difficult. The sound quality is great, it seems to be well constructed and the price is not prohibitive.
history.review_full:
I have numerous pairs of higher-end headphones but up to this point I have had no gaming headsets, so I was not entirely sure what to expect with the CM Storm Pulse-R headset. I have a teenage son who plays cooperative games on-line with a friend of his and so I let him use them for that purpose. It took very little time for these to show their strengths.

The first thing we noticed with them is that they are very comfortable. The padding is soft and the cans fit over the ear so there is no pressure on the ear itself. They can be worn for a good period of time without fatigue. The shape of the headphones themselves looks a little odd and as such I was a little concerned that the fit would be off, but this ended up being a non-issue.

We plugged them into the computer and immediately they lit up. I mean, there are lights on these things and when powered through the USB port they illuminate nicely. They look cool when they’re lit and the lights are not super bright so this is not a bad thing.

The sound quality is very good. We decided to test them out with some music tracks that have a good range of sound and the headphones managed to give us good reproduction of sound without distortion and without overdriving the highs or lows. These are not quite audiophile quality but they are better than a lot of more expensive headphones I have used. The detail is there too so there should be no problem hearing more subtle sounds without cranking the volume too high.

The microphone itself is a little tricky to attach but if one pays attention when trying to attach it, it is not all that difficult. Once connected, it works very well and the noise-canceling aspect of the microphone itself helps to eliminate some of the background noise. The result is a fairly clear transmission of sound.

The cord has three plugs on it: one for the USB power, one for microphone in and one for headphone out. It’s a nice, long cord too, so range of motion is not restrictive.

So far I can’t find too much wrong with this headset. The sound quality is great, it seems to be well constructed and the price is not prohibitive. This is a solid offering the midrange of gaming headsets, and it’s definitely worth a look.

product.title: CM Storm Pulse-R Customizable Aluminum PC Gaming Headset with Detachable Mic and LED Lighting

history.review_excerpt:
They cool the surrounding liquid but they themselves do not melt so the drink is not diluted.

I have worked with other sets of whiskey stones but these are different. Regardless, these freeze well and are ready to go in 1-2 hours.

Dropped in a glass of room-temperature liquid, these start to the chill the liquid almost immediately and they seem to be about as effective as regular ice cubes. The beverage cools fairly fast (though still more slowly than with ice cubes) and because they are sealed they do not dilute the drink at all.

In the package is a small bag that allows for easy storage and transport without getting them oily or dirty. The bag is made of tight nylon and while is nothing fancy it is effective.

If I could change one thing about this product it would be to add 2 to 4 more in the package.
history.review_full:
Whiskey stones are a creative way to chill a drink without diluting it with ice and without having to freeze the cup or glass beforehand. They are usually either stainless steel or soapstone stones and they get chilled in the freezer for a time before hitting the glass. They cool the surrounding liquid but they themselves do not melt so the drink is not diluted.

I have worked with other sets of whiskey stones but these are different. In appearance they are stainless steel stones and there is no reason to believe that they are anything but solid steel cubes when you look at them. However, this is not the case. If you pick one up and shake it gently you can tell quickly that they are actually filled with some form of liquid. It is unclear from the description what this liquid is, but if I had to guess I would assume it is either the same stuff in a freezer pack or an alcohol based slurry. Regardless, these freeze well and are ready to go in 1-2 hours.

Dropped in a glass of room-temperature liquid, these start to the chill the liquid almost immediately and they seem to be about as effective as regular ice cubes. The beverage cools fairly fast (though still more slowly than with ice cubes) and because they are sealed they do not dilute the drink at all.

In the package is a small bag that allows for easy storage and transport without getting them oily or dirty. The bag is made of tight nylon and while is nothing fancy it is effective.

If I could change one thing about this product it would be to add 2 to 4 more in the package. Four is certainly enough to cool a single beverage, but more allows for sharing with a friend. Adding more cubes is not a functional difference, but more of a social one.

I like these cooling cubes. They work a little better than solid stainless steel cubes and they are ready to go in less time in the freezer than other cubes. This is a nice set and I have no issue with recommending it. Just keep in mind that there are only four in the set; if you want to have a drink with a friend you may need another set.

Disclaimer: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.
history.review_title: A Little Better than Solid Stainless Steel Cubes

product.title: Rii Set of 4 Stainless Steel Chilling Reusable Wine Ice Cubes, Whiskey Chilling Rocks, Whisky Stones

history.review_excerpt:
To summarize in a single sentence, this is not a one-size-fits-all gaming mouse, though most serious gamers will appreciate it after getting used to it.

My issue with it is not really the size. My son loves this mouse and says it is the best gaming mouse he has used so far, and since he is the primary user I can't complain – much.

Other than the subtly odd shape, this is a nice mouse. Time will tell, of course.

I am used to mice that have 3, 5 and occasionally 7 buttons. Using the included software, this is a highly programmable mouse and you can set the bank of 12 side buttons as you like, which is a great advantage when gaming to have complicated functions mapped to a single button.
history.review_full:
I have been looking for a good gaming mouse for my teenage son who is a bit fussy about the mouse he uses when gaming with friends. His requirements are simple but pointed – it needs to be fast, it needs to be comfortable in his hand, and it cannot hesitate or skip. For him, this mouse fits the bill nicely and it has worked out for him. For me, I have found that it is slightly awkward to use. To summarize in a single sentence, this is not a one-size-fits-all gaming mouse, though most serious gamers will appreciate it after getting used to it.

My issue with it is not really the size. I like a larger mouse and this one is definitely large enough to fit my hand. However, the shape is a bit strange to me and it feels funny when I try to work with it. This is a personal preference but it is important enough to me to make mention of it. My son loves this mouse and says it is the best gaming mouse he has used so far, and since he is the primary user I can't complain – much.

Other than the subtly odd shape, this is a nice mouse. It is very responsive and precise which is critical for gaming mice of any kind. It seems to be quite durable and well constructed too so it should be able to handle some serious abuse. Time will tell, of course.

I am used to mice that have 3, 5 and occasionally 7 buttons. This one has 17! Using the included software, this is a highly programmable mouse and you can set the bank of 12 side buttons as you like, which is a great advantage when gaming to have complicated functions mapped to a single button. This can also be a curse if you have so many things assigned that you lose track of what is mapped to each button.

This really is a good gaming mouse that will serve well. It is well made and highly configurable. In my case I do not like the hand feel, but for my gamer son it has quickly become critical equipment.

product.title: Corsair Scimitar Pro RGB - MMO Gaming Mouse - 16,000 DPI Optical Sensor - 12 Programmable Side Buttons - Black

history.review_excerpt:
For someone with really small hands this might not be the very best fit, but for the average person or someone with larger than average hands, this one is a comfortable fit.

The mouse comes with two sets of replaceable side panels, which connect to the mouse body via magnets and provide different button layouts. People with more business uses for this mouse may not care, though having the buttons available does allow for setting up speed buttons.

This is a wired mouse (as most quality gaming mice are) and the cable is encased in braided nylon. The sensor is a red LED underneath and it works well enough on non-reflective surfaces (rare is the mouse that works on glass or a mirror).

The precision can be set as high as 12,000 DPI and that is useful for when you’re doing serious pixel work in image processing.
history.review_full:
I have a son who is a gamer and I selected this mouse for him. The mouse he has been using for gaming has worked out well enough, though it is an inexpensive gaming mouse and it shows. I don’t care for the hand feel, either. I was unaware that Alienware gaming mice even existed but based on their laptops and tower systems I made the assumption that this would be a good one. I was right.

First things first – I have large hands and most mice do not fit my hands too well. This one is slightly larger than the average and as such it does fit my hands a little better. For someone with really small hands this might not be the very best fit, but for the average person or someone with larger than average hands, this one is a comfortable fit.

The mouse comes with two sets of replaceable side panels, which connect to the mouse body via magnets and provide different button layouts. Serious gamers will like the configurability and will appreciate having more buttons available. People with more business uses for this mouse may not care, though having the buttons available does allow for setting up speed buttons.

This is a wired mouse (as most quality gaming mice are) and the cable is encased in braided nylon. This should last a good while and resist fatigue. In my experience, the cables often wear out before the mouse itself does.

This mouse is a smooth operator. The buttons are solid and there does not seem to be any hitches in the moving parts. The thumb wheel works well and is smooth. The sensor is a red LED underneath and it works well enough on non-reflective surfaces (rare is the mouse that works on glass or a mirror).

The precision can be set as high as 12,000 DPI and that is useful for when you’re doing serious pixel work in image processing. I can’t really comment on how it does for gaming, though for someone with a really steady hand and a good eye this pinpoint accuracy can be an edge in a tight game.

And…it works under Linux! I plugged it into my Linux machine and it immediately started working. It required no drivers and it just worked. I did not try everything with it, but the main functions work flawlessly. No complaints.

This is not an inexpensive mouse, but you get what you pay for with it. It is designed to be a serious gaming mouse and it has some good features that make it suitable not just for serious gaming but also for really labor-intensive image processing and pixel work. It works under Linux too, which is just the cherry on top.
history.review_title: Good for Gaming and for Pixel Work; Works Under Linux

product.title: Alienware Elite Gaming Mouse

heldout.review_excerpt:
I am writing this review from the perspective not as a gamer but rather as a user who needs a comfortable pointing device. Because of this I have spent a good deal of time researching other options for pointing devices that are comfortable, including writing/art tablets, track balls, pens and more. The system saw the dongle, loaded the drivers it needed and the mouse was dead as a doornail because it needed to be charged so it still did not work. I did not have access to all of the extra programmable buttons but the basic functions worked which is all I really need.

I realize I am not the normal user for such a mouse as this, but in my case this mouse works well for me and I am very pleased.
heldout.review_full:
I am writing this review from the perspective not as a gamer but rather as a user who needs a comfortable pointing device. If you’re looking for reviews on what a wonderful gaming mouse this is, my review isn’t going to help you very much. If you instead want to know how it works for someone with big hands that does a lot of photo and drawing work, I have something to offer here.

I have the hands of a gorilla (seriously, I can palm a basketball) and I have had a terrible time finding a mouse that actually fits my hand properly. Because of this I have spent a good deal of time researching other options for pointing devices that are comfortable, including writing/art tablets, track balls, pens and more. I was not thinking about this when I selected this mouse; instead, I was thinking of my son who is a gamer and is always looking for a better mouse. I’m keeping this one for myself.

A lot of the reviews here mention that it is a claw-grip mouse, not a palm grip. I disagree, though I admit that I am not a typical user. It fits comfortably in my hand and I can rest the base of my palm on the desk and still reach the buttons comfortably without strain. This is good news for me, as most mice are small enough to require me to tuck in my thumb and contort my hand a little to get a good grip which just makes my hands cramp up.

I used the USB dongle to connect to my systems, not Bluetooth, mainly because my Windows computer acts funny with other Bluetooth-based pointing devices. The system saw the dongle, loaded the drivers it needed and the mouse was dead as a doornail because it needed to be charged so it still did not work. I plugged it in, set the mouse to use the USB connection and it worked somewhat as a wired mouse while it charged (it was communicating via the dongle but getting power through the wire). Once charged I disconnected from the power source and it gave me no more issues.

Operation is just as smooth and comfortable as I could hope. The buttons are firm but work well. I have tried all of the “standard” buttons and they work just fine – left-click, right-click, page forward, page backward and scroll. These are all I really need, though I like having the other buttons available should I need them later.

The precision is good and it works well for pixel-peeping when working with digital images. That’s about as close to gaming as I will get with this mouse. I need precision, not speed.

So, the main event for me: I plugged in the dongle in my Linux laptop and set the mouse to talk to it. I did not have access to all of the extra programmable buttons but the basic functions worked which is all I really need.

I realize I am not the normal user for such a mouse as this, but in my case this mouse works well for me and I am very pleased. It fits my hands very well and it just works.
heldout.review_title: Good for Giant Hands; Works Under Linux

history.review_full:
[[VIDEOID:499ac84584cf56f9db85b46180571b61]] This is my first experience with Thrustmaster and a wheel in general. My expectations based on price and the Thrustmaster name were not completely met with the T128P for PS4/5 and PC. It’s a great $100 wheel but slightly above average $200 wheel. Primary user of the wheel is my 12 year old son but for testing purposes I have been driving race cars like I stole them, lol.

Arrival: The wheel arrived nicely package all component were in working order with no issues. However, I immediately notice some of the creature comforts I expected were missing based on price of the wheel such as cushion wheel or higher quality buttons with smooth action.

Instructions: Th instruction for setup were clear except for the computer driver download portion. A little more emphasis and larger font would be nice. Took me a second to locate them due to size of font.

Wheel: The wheel itself is made of hard plastics, buttons appear of low quality and make a loud audible click when pushed, especially the paddles shifters. They lack the quality you see with PS5 and the Xbox elite 2 controllers. The clamp worked fine but make sure you have room underneath your desk to attach, see pictures.

Pedals: I have similar thoughts when it comes to the pedals. The pedals assembly is very light and lack common sense in the design. It doesn’t take and engineer to understand center of gravity and how a lever works. To explain the pedals will slide forward when in use and have a tendency to want to pitch forward off the floor due the center of gravity begin shifted so far forward and the lack of weight to counter this affect. The design seemed to completely overlook that someone had to actually use this in game under various conditions. I guess that is why a pedal stand is sold by Thrustmaster as an accessory for ~$90. Just my thoughts but human in the loop and ergonomics should be considered in the design process hint…hint. You have to hold the pedals in place with your off foot, use a weight or hey buy their pedal stand.

Hooking up: Once everything was hooked up it was first tested on the PS5 with no issues. Worked well with GT7. For the computer…driver download was easy. Thrustmaster done have control panel for making adjustments to the settings. We first tried with Forza 4 and had issues. The game would not recognize the wheel. However, after some internet research we found this is a common issue across many brands of wheels and Forza 4. I found no immediate work around so we tried using the wheel with Forza 5. The wheel was recognized as a T248 and Forza auto-configured the wheel. The wheel worked as intended with all features being functional. My son did adjust the button layout to his liking. When also tried the wheel with the Crew 2 demo and it worked but not as well. Not all function worked on the wheel, mainly the center shift lights were not operable. This could be due to the game being only a demo though.

So to wrap this up the wheel is a good beginner wheel but without the creature comforts I expected for the price point. The design lacks in key areas of functionality and quality, especially regarding the pedals and use of quality components such as buttons. The dynamic functionality of the wheel lacks the feel I expected and in my opinion is cheap considering the price.

Note: the cord routing and layout could have been incorporated better considering it is a clamp on type mount. The cords are easily pinch during mounting and do not stay in the routing channels.

My review is solely based on my experience with this wheel and isn’t biased as I have never owned another.
history.review_title: Good beginner wheel but expected more for the price point.

My only complaint is with the design. Due to the curve of the base my forth and fifth fingers do not have a comfortable resting spot. I can live with it but that should have been taken into consideration. I have small hands and a person with larger hands is likely to have more of an issue.

heldout.review_excerpt:
To sum it up, design, quality, sound, comfort are all average to slightly above. If you expected top of the line headset at this price point that is putting unrealistic expectation on the product.

The design could be improved to increase flexibility and range of motion of the ear cups. Not every head is shaped the same.

Sound could be better but the sound works just fine. It is clear and loud all though you do not have the atmosphere of a higher priced headset such as Astro. It is hard to find the button.

The headset connects easily via the USB transmitter or blue tooth. I had no issues connecting to my PC or using the USB transmitter with my sons PlayStation 5.
heldout.review_full:
The BINNUNE Dual Wireless Gaming Headset with Microphone is a descent headset and priced accordingly. It arrived nicely packaged with no issues. To sum it up, design, quality, sound, comfort are all average to slightly above. If you expected top of the line headset at this price point that is putting unrealistic expectation on the product.

The design could be improved to increase flexibility and range of motion of the ear cups. That would improve comfort. Not every head is shaped the same.

Sound could be better but the sound works just fine. It is clear and loud all though you do not have the atmosphere of a higher priced headset such as Astro. It’s not a deep rich sound you would find with a Higher end gaming headset.

The microphone could be improved to better the noise cancellation. That would help it not pick up as much background noise. Also, it could have a swivel mic mute in addition to a button. It is hard to find the button.

The headset connects easily via the USB transmitter or blue tooth. I had no issues connecting to my PC or using the USB transmitter with my sons PlayStation 5. Note, it’s is only for PS not Xbox.

Overall, it is a good affordable headset for entry level gaming or evening office work like I use it for. I have used with teams and webex with no issues.
heldout.review_title: Entry level headset good for gaming or office work.

I hadn't gotten back into Guitar Hero/Rock Band in quite some time, mostly because I wore out my old guitars. This came up to review and I was more than happy to give it a try.
After setting up CloneHero on my PC, I got the guitar assembled (super easy, 2 parts and some batteries). I followed the instructions included to get it set up (as a keyboard) in CloneHero, and away I went! I had to adjust the hardware input calibration a bit, but then I was playing again! It feels exactly like my Guitar Hero controllers of old, nice stiff buttons and very responsive. The whammy bar works great, and the tilt to activate star power never missed for me. 100% recommend to get back into the rhythm games!

Edit - A couple things to add.
• I wear glasses, these are reasonably when wearing glasses.

heldout.review_full:
[[VIDEOID:27650cd0317fc1e6114d8bac39cb39d6]] These headphones sound really good. They're not world class but as far as affordable headphones go these fit the bill. I listened to a variety of music, classical, jazz, rock, prog, metal and using the Bass mode EQ/sound effect setting. I'm very amused the headphones pronounce bass like the fish. Other than Bass mode these have; Classic and Vocal modes.
Bass mode worked well once I adjusted the equalizers in my tablet and phone. A little fish, I mean bass, heavy but the highs are there, fairly sharp and clear.
Classic mode is the happy medium setting. I find this is good for listening to YouTube channels where someone is talking/reacting to something.
Vocal mode. . . Maybe good for phone calls? Unfortunately I didn't receive or make any calls. Honestly this mode made everything sound horrible.
The lighting is rather cool you can have static single colors, I was particularly fond of the green and red they're very vibrant but all the colors are well done. Then you can have your single color pulse/fade in and out, next you you can cycle all the colors one after the other. Finally you can have a color chasing rainbow where all the colors display and cycle around in a circle. This is my favorite mode. My only complaint is you can't see the groovy colors when you're wearing the headphones!
The microphone on these is clever. There's just a small nub not much bigger than a pencil's eraser that protrudes from the front of the left side. you gently pull on this to extend the microphone boom. It easily slides back into the headphone. It appears that even though the unit has a memory function, remembering color settings and which sound mode you used, you apparently have to mute the microphone each time you power on the unit.
Fit and finish are good, not great, I've got a kinda large head and these are just the slightest bit tight but I'd rather that than loose. I used them for a couple hours last night then fell asleep with them on and woke up hours later. They can be worn a long time. Cups are nicely soft and breathe okay. In a warm room you may sweat. I'm not sure these are suitable for kids or irresponsible teens/adults. The hinges that allow you to lay these flat look like metal but they're plastic. Heavy play, flexing too much and they'll break. They're hefty but have a very soft pad that sits on top of your head.
Battery life seems to be excellent. I had the rainbow colors cycling and had them powered on for over nine hours and they were playing at least six, my tablet rebooted sometime after I fell asleep.
As an affordable set of headphones that sound pretty dang good (adjust your devices EQ if it has one) have long battery life and fit well these are something I would definitely recommend.

P. S.
I know some reviewers have said these are too quiet or very quiet. I don't blast my ears like I did growing up (I'm 56) so with the volume on the headset maxed and each device having the sound up, never maxed, these were more than loud enough to hear everything I listened to.

Edit - A couple things to add.
• I wear glasses, these are reasonably when wearing glasses.
• I needed to open the headband up two notches on each side for a better fit. I just wanted to note that the corners of the plastic exposed when opened are pointy and quite sharp!
• Had an accidental durability test the other day. I was sitting in my wheelchair when a nurse came in to talk to me. I pushed my headphones up and a little too far. They fell approximately four feet onto a tile floor. Absolutely no damage.
• If you put these on and can't hear anything even after checking the volume in whatever app you're using and your system settings. Check the volume wheel on the headset, It's really easy to accidentally roll it all the way down.

history.review_excerpt:
It also comes with a magnetic type-c connector for your goggles.

By cutting a small hole in the silicone sleeve, I'm able to charge the controllers without removing the sleeve and the cables are easy to connect because of the magnetic connectors. The goggle is just as easy to charge with its corresponding magnetic connector.

There are two problems with this system that you need to be aware of, though. The charging speed will suffer as a result.

Overall, not having to go through the hassle of removing the silicone sleeve to change batteries makes this kit worth the purchase. I don't have long play sessions with the VR system so I'm not so worried about charging speed.
history.review_full:
The fancy docks that you see for the Quest 2 usually has a place for charging the goggles, and two spots for the controllers. The only problem is that the docks are made for the controllers without the silicone sleeves that people usually put on their controllers. In fact, there aren't many solutions out there that allow charging while using the silicone sleeves.

With this All-in-One Magnetic Charging Kit for Oculus Quest 2, I'm able to resolve all of my problems. This system is well thought out. It comes with two rechargeable batteries and special battery covers that expose a magnetic charging port on the side of the controller. It also comes with a magnetic type-c connector for your goggles.

By cutting a small hole in the silicone sleeve, I'm able to charge the controllers without removing the sleeve and the cables are easy to connect because of the magnetic connectors. The goggle is just as easy to charge with its corresponding magnetic connector.

There are two problems with this system that you need to be aware of, though. The first is that the type-c connector is not very strong. It means that when pulling off the charging cable, the type-c plug with come with it. The second problem is that the three devices will be sharing a single cable and thus, sharing the available amps. The charging speed will suffer as a result.

Overall, not having to go through the hassle of removing the silicone sleeve to change batteries makes this kit worth the purchase. I don't have long play sessions with the VR system so I'm not so worried about charging speed.
history.review_title: No need for a fancy dock.

history.review_excerpt:
It takes a little bit of digging to actually know which one is worth getting.

The listing doesn't say it but this controller's brand is Sound Fox. I programmed a series of presses, holds and wait times that allowed me to go through the menu 5 times with each press of the programmable button.

What's more, the vibration strength is programmable, the face plate is easily removeable (although I haven't seen replacement faceplates available) and even Amiibo support is built in. Aside from the smaller size, this is a great replacement for the Pro controller.

history.review_full:
There are many third-party switch controllers on the market and each make claims about compatibility or useability. It takes a little bit of digging to actually know which one is worth getting.

The listing doesn't say it but this controller's brand is Sound Fox. It is a fairly compact controller that is noticeably smaller than the Switch Pro controller. It is actually well-built and has a great texture. The entire controller feels soft and satin with nice analog sticks that don't feel loose. The buttons feel good and the digital pad is fairly standard.

Outside of these basic features, the controller has two programmable buttons in the back and turbo mode for all of the face and shoulder buttons. The programmable buttons actually can remember fairly long sequences of button presses and digital pad inputs. I used it to go through some particularly annoying menus in Xenoblade 3 that I needed to do over and over again (collectopedia). I programmed a series of presses, holds and wait times that allowed me to go through the menu 5 times with each press of the programmable button.

What's more, the vibration strength is programmable, the face plate is easily removeable (although I haven't seen replacement faceplates available) and even Amiibo support is built in. It really is a good value for the price. Aside from the smaller size, this is a great replacement for the Pro controller.

On the PC, this is a great bluetooth controller that can operate in Xinput mode for maximum game compatibility. This feature is something you don't find in many other third party controllers out there.

The only problem I have with this controller is the fact that the ZL and ZR triggers are digital only. When using this controller on the PC, you really need to have analog triggers to get the most out of many games.

In the end, this product is geared toward the Switch and has the added option to be used on the PC and mobile phones but without analog triggers, it really is only good on the Switch.
history.review_title: Smaller than I expected, but still useable.

history.review_full:
[[VIDEOID:bcce61b61b8337c3b68e072c0d20d249]] I had a USB gaming headset that worked fairly well. It had large speakers that gave the sound a "roomy" feeling, especially when paired with the driver software that it came with, but the wire was driving me crazy. I couldn't step away from my desk without removing a few things or I'd end up pulling away my computer with me.

So, I was in the market for a nice pair of wireless gaming headsets. I've come across many in the 30-dollar range but none of the descriptions for those touted surround sound. Eventually, I had to look in the 60 - 90 range.

This pair of OCG Gaming Headsets 2.4GHz Bluetooth Wireless Gaming Headphones were just what I needed. I wanted bluetooth capabilities because I wanted to have it as an option in case I wanted to pair it to two computers (one via dongle and one via bluetooth). I also wanted the option of using it with other gaming systems such as an XBox or Playstation. The usb dongle gives that versatility.

I really don't care much for RGB as they just make my computers distracting and I'm not a game streamer or youtuber (not yet, anyway, ha ha), but if you do like them, this headset has them...

So, what do I think? I'd been playing Uncharted 4 on my PC with my old pair of headphones and it sounded great. The surround didn't really seem like it worked very well. After I received the OCG, I plugged in the USB dongle and booted up the game. The game automatically detected the headset and showed that it was using virtual surround. Immediately, I found that I was hearing sounds that I hadn't heard before!

As the character walked around, I heard the jangling sounds of the equipment he had at his belt, I heard the companion character talking behind me and as I turned, her voice moved around my head. I was super impressed!

I then disconnected the dongle and tried the headset in bluetooth mode. The sound was a little muffled and there was almost no surround effect, even though the game still said that it was doing virtual surround.

So I'm definitely using the dongle for all my gaming. I love this thing!
history.review_title: I've been looking for an affordable headset with surround.  This fit my needs.

history.review_full:
After a couple of years of intense gaming on my XBox One controller, the rubber on my left analog stick pretty much rubbed smooth, losing grip. Eventually, the rubber actually rubbed off. Add to that, the right stick began to stick a little for some reason.

I knew it was time to attempt a repair. While doing so, I thought I'd pick interesting colors for the analog sticks to make it fun. I bought the TOMSIN Replacement Joysticks for Xbox One Series X/S Controller in the Nintendo Switch blue/red combo.

The installation was straightforward. Just followed a teardown video on youtube and used the included tools. The tools came in handy to pry the plastic open and unscrew the screws holding the controller together.

Replacement was simple. Just pull off the old analog sticks and pop in the new ones. They fit perfectly and now, I have a controller that feels new and responsive. Great product.

heldout.review_excerpt:
The electronics present themselves as a native PS4 controller, including being able to work with DS4Windows (when connected to a PC).

The controller has all of the functionality that you'd expect. The touch pad, LED lights, and 6-axis gyro all work as well. When holding it, the buttons feel too far away from the thumb and the stick locations feel wrong.

During use, I had some issues with the turbo turning on randomly which was very confusing. I didn't know why I couldn't jump in the game because the jump button was on turbo.

So in the end, while this controller does what it says, I still am always thinking that I should have just gotten the original while using it.
heldout.review_full:
The OUBANG Remote for PS4 Controller Elite is a PS4 controller from the point of view of the computer or the console. The electronics present themselves as a native PS4 controller, including being able to work with DS4Windows (when connected to a PC).

The controller has all of the functionality that you'd expect. All buttons, sticks, and triggers work as expected. The touch pad, LED lights, and 6-axis gyro all work as well. On top of this, the controller has programmable back buttons and turbo mode.

The main problem with this controller comes when you first hold it. The ergonomics of the controller is off. When holding it, the buttons feel too far away from the thumb and the stick locations feel wrong.

During use, I had some issues with the turbo turning on randomly which was very confusing. I didn't know why I couldn't jump in the game because the jump button was on turbo.

So in the end, while this controller does what it says, I still am always thinking that I should have just gotten the original while using it.
heldout.review_title: Mimics a PS4 controller in terms of connectivity, but quality doesn't match the original.  Bad ergo.
