history.review_excerpt:
Pretty soon, I had this shell, a “white” digitizer (which ended up actually being gray), a new LDC (because separating the original screen from the digitizer seemed like a good way to break it), thermal paste, screen adhesive, and a fan (because mine has been sounding a bit loud lately, but the one I ordered ended up not fitting, so I just cleaned the original one well and reinstalled it). Even if, at the end of the day, the screen bezel ended up being gray, I feel like it is the best end product I could have ended up with and the one that makes me most happy.

Update 9/22: this shell had me a little worried since the soft-touch finish feels like it will wear off with use.
history.review_full:
Last Friday night I noticed my OEM switch shell was no longer closing correctly; likely due to case clips breaking during one of the two times I have replaced my left joystick (this Switch Lite has at leas 1000 hours of play time, and is the only Switch controller that I have had drift issues with). By midnight, I had fully fallen down the shell swap rabbit-hole.

I decided on this pink case, but having a turquoise Switch Lite, I was apprehensive about the screen bezel as I don’t feel like a screen protector is the best solution. Pretty soon, I had this shell, a “white” digitizer (which ended up actually being gray), a new LDC (because separating the original screen from the digitizer seemed like a good way to break it), thermal paste, screen adhesive, and a fan (because mine has been sounding a bit loud lately, but the one I ordered ended up not fitting, so I just cleaned the original one well and reinstalled it). Overall, the price was a bit much considering this was an impulse purchase in the middle of the night, but I did what I did and I don’t really have any regrets about it.

The swap took a little over an hour to complete (remember, I didn’t remove the old screen, so I got done a little quicker - besides, this isn’t a race). It wasn’t too hard, but I had already disassembled my Switch Lite a couple times for joystick replacements, so I felt well prepared (plus I watched some videos and reviewed iFixIt’s screen replacement instructions). I didn’t find anything to be terribly difficult, only tedious. Anyone who has the right tools, takes their time, keeps track of their screws, and follows instructions shouldn’t have too much of an issue with this swap. If you have ever replaced a joystick, you shouldn’t have much of an issue with this.

Things to note: The finish on this case feels velvety soft- very pleasant in the hand. It makes me wonder how it will hold up to wear and use in the long term though. I have seem some reviews that show what looks like the finish wearing off, but those switches were put into cases. I haven’t seen anyone who uses their switch lite naked complaining of issues- only time will tell. This case also has a less than 1mm gap along the top and bottom - isn’t really anything that will ruin my day, but I felt it needed to be mentioned since I can’t account for it (putting the tiniest amount of pressure on the case closes the gap - I made sure my screws in the back of the case were tight, but still, there is a gap). Other than that, I am very happy with the way this turned out :)

Tips for success:
-Have the right tools. You will need 00 Philips, 00 Tri-wing, Spudgers, adhesive (in case the screen adhesive isn’t usable when you remove the old one or want to use a new one), thermal paste (it isn’t really expensive and will save your device from overheating), heat gun (if you aren’t replacing the screen with a new one)
-Take your time - this isn’t a race. A mod that takes 60 minutes instead of 4 hours is not worth it if you break your device.
-Clean as you go - If you are using a switch lite that has been around, you will likely find dust and grime inside, have some rubbing alcohol and canned air to clean anything you run into. Just make sure any alcohol you use has evaporated before turning the device back on.
-Replace any parts you have concerns about. The fan and joysticks are common parts that fail. If you have issues that you notice (loud fan or slight drift), use this opportunity to swap the part(s) while you are in there. That being said, the fan I bought ended up not fitting my Switch Lite - I cleaned it out well with cabbed air while the device was open (see Clean as you go) and it runs much better now.
-Follow instructions. iFixIt has a screen replacement guide that I followed. It identified the screw type for each hole. I separated my screws by size and had no problem grabbing the right one for each step when I reassembled.

A little more on why I decided to replace my screen and digitizer. At the end of the day, I wanted to end up with a mod that made me most happy and a screen protector wouldn’t do that (nor would a turquoise bezel around the screen). In addition to being a better fit for my desired outcome, it gave me the flexibility to more easily move back into the old case if I ever felt the need (or ended up breaking the screen). I considered trying to separate the digitizer, but decided it was too risky (in hindsight, it probably would have been fine). Even if, at the end of the day, the screen bezel ended up being gray, I feel like it is the best end product I could have ended up with and the one that makes me most happy.

Update 9/22: this shell had me a little worried since the soft-touch finish feels like it will wear off with use. I am happy to report that I see no signs of an issue after 10 months of use. I will note that the shell makes the switch 7g heavier than the original for anyone interested.
history.review_title: My Switch Lite is freaking adorable

history.review_excerpt: I'm happy to say the experience was positive, the headphones were comfortable to wear and the sound was excellent- definitely crisper and better bass response than the classic Apple buds I've been using on this laptop before trying these (and what I'm using for baseline comparison purposes). The microphone is excellent as well, I like that it aims in front of your mouth so it doesn't pick up ambient room noise and echo voice like other headsets which have the mic on the line or even worse, on the earphone itself (I've almost never had a good experience with a mic on your ear!). But that's no fault of this product, as gamer / audiophile 'phones are usually the bulky variety and it is expected.
history.review_full:
I've had good experiences with Skullcandy before, but this is my first time trying their Wage brand of headsets. I'm happy to say the experience was positive, the headphones were comfortable to wear and the sound was excellent- definitely crisper and better bass response than the classic Apple buds I've been using on this laptop before trying these (and what I'm using for baseline comparison purposes). The microphone is excellent as well, I like that it aims in front of your mouth so it doesn't pick up ambient room noise and echo voice like other headsets which have the mic on the line or even worse, on the earphone itself (I've almost never had a good experience with a mic on your ear!). And the best feature is the way the mic will mute if you lift the mic boom arm up away from your face, and then come back when repositioned. A physical action like that is far better than a button or switch.
The only catch is that you need to be into the gamer's aesthetic. Someone in our home wanted to use these for Zoom meetings, and found that she didn't like looking like she had such a large headset- it didn't go with the look she wanted to have on camera. But that's no fault of this product, as gamer / audiophile 'phones are usually the bulky variety and it is expected. I think this is a really solid options for gamers.
history.review_title: Great and clear audio and classic gamer style!

history.review_excerpt: My daughter wanted to try these to replace her older busted BT headphones, and so far she really likes them! The sound quality is pretty decent, more bass than expected and that's definitely a feature on smaller buds. The build quality was pretty good too, but I'm personally not a fan of touch-controls. My daughter says she doesn't mind this because she doesn't touch her ears as much when wearing them, so maybe this is something that doesn't effect all people. The microphone quality isn't great at isolating your voice, you get a lot of background noise but that's all common for this style of ear bud. It's not perfect, but for the money it's actually pretty good.
history.review_full: My daughter wanted to try these to replace her older busted BT headphones, and so far she really likes them! I got the pink variant, and the color makes her really happy- even the case is pink, which isn't how the last pair we got worked (only part of the ear buds were colored on that one, and not the case at all). The sound quality is pretty decent, more bass than expected and that's definitely a feature on smaller buds. The build quality was pretty good too, but I'm personally not a fan of touch-controls. I've owned a pair like them before and found that I would accidentally activate things every time I reseated them for comfort in my ear / keep them from falling out. My daughter says she doesn't mind this because she doesn't touch her ears as much when wearing them, so maybe this is something that doesn't effect all people. The microphone quality isn't great at isolating your voice, you get a lot of background noise but that's all common for this style of ear bud. history.review_excerpt:
I mean, you could easily set this up yourself with dozens of tutorials online, and arguably the entire purpose of a Raspberry Pi is the DIY part of it.
However, that assumes you have a spare memory card to commit to the project, as well as the time to read up on it and actually set it up properly. That's a reasonable argument.
And personally, I always said I wanted to do this to one of my Pi boards, but never did. Now that I've gotten an opportunity to try this, I see the value in not re-creating the wheel when someone has already put in the time for me.
I'm still a fan of DIY if you have the time and a spare card, but I'll happily spend the time I saved playing some classic Mario on this one.
history.review_full:
As a DIY enthusiast who's bought and installed Pis for all kinds of things, I was a skeptical about this product's purpose and value. I mean, you could easily set this up yourself with dozens of tutorials online, and arguably the entire purpose of a Raspberry Pi is the DIY part of it.
However, that assumes you have a spare memory card to commit to the project, as well as the time to read up on it and actually set it up properly. For only a little bit more than the cost of a memory card, you can get this one already set up with everything you'd ever need or want. That's a reasonable argument.
And personally, I always said I wanted to do this to one of my Pi boards, but never did. Now that I've gotten an opportunity to try this, I see the value in not re-creating the wheel when someone has already put in the time for me.
I'm still a fan of DIY if you have the time and a spare card, but I'll happily spend the time I saved playing some classic Mario on this one.

This is a great gamer's mousepad for a few major reasons. But more than that, it actually responds well to the different brand mice I have tried (great response and feedback from movement), and is big enough to have your keyboard in the middle yet have some room for the mouse on EITHER SIDE! That means you can mix it up and swap hands as needed for games that you might require more dexterity with one hand vs the other! Or if you have friends that are different-brained than you, or perhaps you are ambidextrous... the possibilities go on!
Just measure first and make sure there's enough room. My old computer desk had a pull out keyboard that was narrower than this mat is, so make sure you have a large enough surface like a tabletop for it.

I am not a fan of the buttons on both sides. I ultimately disabled the buttons on the right, but I can appreciate the fact Razer is keeping it's left-handed customers in mind.

All-in-all, I am a big fan of Razer products, but disappointed in the price of this mouse and the quality.
history.review_full:
This mouse is light as AIR. It's a bit bigger than I anticipated, but the weight compensates for the size.

The battery life is something to be desired. I followed the instructions on charging out of the box, however I have yet to hit100% battery charge despite long hours of charging. 97% is the closest to full. I game and work on social media and spend roughly 2-4 hours at least on the device daily. I have had to charge the mouse every day I have owned it.

The connection fails randomly which has not helped my KDR. If this doesn't fix itself I'll be returning it. It's a shame because my AK spray has improved significantly since using this mouse.

I am not a fan of the buttons on both sides. I ultimately disabled the buttons on the right, but I can appreciate the fact Razer is keeping it's left-handed customers in mind.

All-in-all, I am a big fan of Razer products, but disappointed in the price of this mouse and the quality. I'm dedicated to the company and hope to find resolutions to these issues.

heldout.review_excerpt:
I hestitated to upgrade considering the reviews for users with smaller hands were so poor, but I am in love with this new Tartarus keypad.

I see a lot of users comparing it to the Nostromo, and while I understand the argument of size, it's also important to take into account there is an additional entire row of keys on the Tartarus. Sure they are a bit more challenging to reach with smaller hands, but in gaming I have them as programed as my numbered inventory and in editing for less used keys.

The padding is really soft and the product is very durable and feels superior in it's quality compared to the Nostromo.
heldout.review_full:
I'm a 5'0 female and have extreme baby hands. I've been using the Nostromo for years, but unfortunately it's been fading fast. I hestitated to upgrade considering the reviews for users with smaller hands were so poor, but I am in love with this new Tartarus keypad.

I see a lot of users comparing it to the Nostromo, and while I understand the argument of size, it's also important to take into account there is an additional entire row of keys on the Tartarus. Mind you, that missing row of keys drove me INSANE and I am so happy they added it. Sure they are a bit more challenging to reach with smaller hands, but in gaming I have them as programed as my numbered inventory and in editing for less used keys.

The padding is really soft and the product is very durable and feels superior in it's quality compared to the Nostromo. The d-pad is night and day compared to the old model and much easier to use. The only physical draw back I've found after several hours of use so far is the scroll wheel feels somewhat fragile.

The software is very simple to use and still offers a seemingly endless amount of options to personalize the device's use. Having my mouse work seamlessly with the device, and even together with programing options, is a huge plus.

If you have smaller hands and are transitioning from the Nostromo it's important to remember the addition of the 4th row (which is fabulous). If you are using a razer keypad for the first time, I would suggest some patience and assure you that you will grow to love it.

Well worth it.
heldout.review_title: Actual baby hands (5'0 female) and I LOVE my new keypad

history.review_excerpt:
We had been looking forward, planning on getting this smaller size since it was announce. It came as a huge disappointment when we learned we would not be able to purchase this size after all. After using them I can happily say we are pleased with the smaller size. Having to spend $220.00 is a high price for anyone only interested in the New 3ds. It's really not a big deal for us because we love Animal Crossing so much.
Of course, the new included game can not compare to the original Animal Crossing game, but it's enjoyable for what it is. We would love to see some of the things from ACHHD included in the next true Animal Crossing game.
history.review_full:
Finally, we in the U.S. get to buy the New Nintendo 3ds. We had been looking forward, planning on getting this smaller size since it was announce. It came as a huge disappointment when we learned we would not be able to purchase this size after all. After using them I can happily say we are pleased with the smaller size. It's convenient for carrying if you have a smaller purse. I like the lighter feel of it in my hands. The cover plates are definitely fun!
The only down side is for those that weren't interested in purchasing the game, or the cover plates. Having to spend $220.00 is a high price for anyone only interested in the New 3ds. It's really not a big deal for us because we love Animal Crossing so much.
Of course, the new included game can not compare to the original Animal Crossing game, but it's enjoyable for what it is. We would love to see some of the things from ACHHD included in the next true Animal Crossing game.

product.title: Nintendo Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer + New 3DS Bundle

history.review_excerpt:
After playing my own game included with the New 3ds, I don't feel there is any pressing need for the amiibo cards, since the game itself isn't that deep, and the character's will eventually show up.

I made a mistake on the placement of Katt's house. When I restarted, I was sad to discover Katt was not there, but other character's were. I have purchased a lot of the amiibo cards, but have not felt the need to use one with the game yet. I would have liked the option to purchase the complete set as a whole.

The last 6-card set I bought only had one card that wasn't a duplicate. After purchasing 21 sets so far from various stores, I'm about to call it quits.
history.review_full:
After playing my own game included with the New 3ds, I don't feel there is any pressing need for the amiibo cards, since the game itself isn't that deep, and the character's will eventually show up.

I made a mistake on the placement of Katt's house. I didn't realize at the time that I could move it later, so turned it off. When I restarted, I was sad to discover Katt was not there, but other character's were. Maybe this could be used to get your favorite villagers without using the cards.

It's my understanding that only the special character's, like Nook, Isabelle, etc., need the amiibo cards if you desire to decorate their homes. I have purchased a lot of the amiibo cards, but have not felt the need to use one with the game yet. I guess I just don't care enough to use the cards, maybe later. We haven't even played the game in a few days.

The Animal Crossing amiibo cards really are cute. My daughter decided she'd like to collect the set. This has proven to be more of a challenge than I realized. I refuse to pay more than retail for an expensive game add on. I would have liked the option to purchase the complete set as a whole.

The last 6-card set I bought only had one card that wasn't a duplicate. I already regret getting caught up it the collecting. I've spent enough money already. After purchasing 21 sets so far from various stores, I'm about to call it quits. At least I haven't paid more than retail for them. Just be patient, it's not like they won't be restocked.

history.review_excerpt: My son and daughter-in-law work full time in a small midwestern town. There aren't many restaurants in town, but there's a Domino Pizza. So, when they don't want to cook, or have students over - my son is a professor - they can serve up some classic Domino Pizza. Figured this would give them an excuse to not cook and have a break. I called the Domino's in their town as recommended to ensure they take gift cards and they do! My daughter-in-law likes this pizza, so figured these gift cards would make her happy!
history.review_full: My son and daughter-in-law work full time in a small midwestern town.  There aren't many restaurants in town, but there's a Domino Pizza.  So, when they don't want to cook, or have students over - my son is a professor - they can serve up some classic Domino Pizza.  Figured this would give them an excuse to not cook and have a break.  I called the Domino's in their town as recommended to ensure they take gift cards and they do!  My daughter-in-law likes this pizza, so figured these gift cards would make her happy!
